user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_set_cork_state_:
```c
bool
MHD_connection_set_cork_state_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                                bool cork_state)
{
#if defined(MHD_TCP_CORK_NOPUSH)
  const MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_ off_val = 0;
  const MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_ on_val = 1;
  int err_code;

  if (_MHD_YES == connection->is_nonip)
    return false;
  if (0 == setsockopt (connection->socket_fd,
                       IPPROTO_TCP,
                       MHD_TCP_CORK_NOPUSH,
                       (const void *) (cork_state ? &on_val : &off_val),
                       sizeof (off_val)))
  {
    connection->sk_corked = cork_state;
    return true;
  }

  err_code = MHD_socket_get_error_ ();
  if (MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err_code, MHD_SCKT_EINVAL_) ||
      MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err_code, MHD_SCKT_ENOPROTOOPT_) ||
      MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err_code, MHD_SCKT_ENOTSOCK_))
  {
    if (_MHD_UNKNOWN == connection->is_nonip)
      connection->is_nonip = _MHD_YES;
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    else
    {
      MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
                _ ("Setting %s option to %s state failed "
                   "for TCP/IP socket %d: %s\n"),
#ifdef TCP_CORK
                "TCP_CORK",
#else  /* ! TCP_CORK */
                "TCP_NOPUSH",
#endif /* ! TCP_CORK */
                cork_state ? _ ("ON") : _ ("OFF"),
                (int) connection->socket_fd,
                MHD_socket_strerr_ (err_code));
    }
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
  }
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  else
  {
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              _ ("Setting %s option to %s state failed: %s\n"),
#ifdef TCP_CORK
              "TCP_CORK",
#else  /* ! TCP_CORK */
              "TCP_NOPUSH",
#endif /* ! TCP_CORK */
              cork_state ? _ ("ON") : _ ("OFF"),
              MHD_socket_strerr_ (err_code));
  }
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */

#else  /* ! MHD_TCP_CORK_NOPUSH */
  (void) connection; (void) cork_state; /* Mute compiler warnings. */
#endif /* ! MHD_TCP_CORK_NOPUSH */
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_connection_set_cork_state_:
#define MHD_TCP_CORK_NOPUSH TCP_CORK
...
typedef int MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_
...
#define MHD_socket_get_error_ (errno)
...
#define MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_(err, code) ((MHD_SCKT_MISSING_ERR_CODE_!=(code))&&((code)==(err)))
...
#define MHD_SCKT_EINVAL_ EINVAL
...
#define MHD_SCKT_ENOPROTOOPT_ ENOPROTOOPT
...
#define MHD_SCKT_ENOTSOCK_ ENOTSOCK
...
void
MHD_DLOG (const struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
          const char *format,
          ...)
{
  va_list va;

  if (0 == (daemon->options & MHD_USE_ERROR_LOG))
    return;
  va_start (va, format);
  daemon->custom_error_log (daemon->custom_error_log_cls,
                            format,
                            va);
  va_end (va);
}
...
#define MHD_socket_strerr_(err) strerror((err))
...
#define HAVE_MESSAGES 1
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the provided function MHD_connection_set_cork_state_ and the related additional code. There are no calls to memcmp anywhere in the target function or in the supplied macros and helper functions, nor are there macros or wrapper functions that expand to memcmp. No code fragment performs a raw memory comparison of null-terminated strings. Other string-related functions (strerror via MHD_socket_strerr_) are only used to obtain diagnostic strings and are not compared with memcmp. Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14.
